text: the terrible first moments after flight
mh17 was shot down these pictures filmed
by a local resident have just been made
available for the first time in fields
strewn with the debris and bodies which
fell from the plane local villagers
struggled preventing the fires spreading
to their crops in the scene today
exactly four months on after long delays
Dutch investigators to finally begun
picking up the pieces of the Malaysian
airliner some larger pieces of fuselage
need to be cut into smaller sections
before they can be taken away the work
is being done by local employees of the
Ministry of emergencies the Dutch side
decides what parts of debris they need
to take away they put stickers on them
and mark the numbers of the debris and
we load them as the work proceeded local
separatists kept a close guard on the
site immediately after the tragedy in
July the first priority was to find the
remains of the 298 passengers and crew
continued fighting in the area has
hampered a recovery work of the plane
itself and the criminal investigation
into who shot it down now a shaky truce
has made it possible
the OSCE say they're glad to get their
hands on the wreckage at last there were
attempts to get at some of the wreckage
especially the what's called the
tell-tale wreckage where you have the
pock marks in the fuselage that's the
section of the aircraft near the cockpit
unfortunately at that time there was
heavy shelling and that that process had
to be stopped so now the the focus of
course is getting again at that part of
the aircraft from the crash site
different sections of the plane are
being taken to a nearby town by trunk
once they've all been assembled there
they'll be taken by train to the city of
Kharkiv which is held by government
forces and from there they'll be taken
to the Netherlands which is leading the
and
national investigation at the request of
Ukraine from the start Ukraine has put
the blame squarely on Russian backed
separatists while the Russian side has
tried to prove that Ukraine shot down a
civilian airliner this debris should
eventually prove which side is telling
the truth
Nik Thorpe BBC news Kiev
